flares.note: Double peaked flare with following M1.2 peak at 2026-02-05T08:46Z.
Double peaked flare with preceeding M1.0 peak at 2026-02-05T08:33Z.
Simultaneous, but more minor, flaring is observed from Active Region 14366 (N14W16) at this time.
Double peaked flare followed by M1.3 peaking at 2026-02-05T16:39Z.
Double peaked flare preceeded by M1.6 peaking at 2026-02-05T16:30Z.

cmes.note: This CME is visible to the southeast in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, GOES CCOR-1, and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source may be related to an eruption and brightening centered near S18E60 starting around 2026-02-04T11:52Z as seen in SDO AIA 131/171/193/304 imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the approximate source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

cmes.note: This CME is visible to the northeast in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, GOES CCOR-1, and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source may be related to an eruption centered near S05E60 starting around 2026-02-04T12:00Z as seen in SDO AIA 131/171/193/304 and GOES SUVI 131/171/193/284/304 imagery. Dimming is observed in SDO AIA 193 imagery at this time, and an opening of field lines can be observed over the eastern limb in GOES SUVI 284 imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the approximate source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

cmes.note: This CME is visible to the northeast in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, GOES CCOR-1, and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source may be related to an eruption centered near N20E23 starting around 2026-02-04T14:00Z as seen in SDO AIA 131/171/193/304 imagery. A subsequent dimming is seen in SDO AIA 193 which appears to deflect northeast of the eruption site.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the approximate source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

cmes.note: CME first seen to the NE by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2026-02-04T18:24Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 and GOES CCOR-1 in later frames. This event is not visible in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap which began at 2026-02-04T15:53Z. The source of this CME was not found in real-time in EUV imagery. Some of the CME material reverts back towards the solar disk and the rest of the material continues to propagate out into the corona. This separation can be seen beginning around 2026-02-04T18:12Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky measurement using a longitude of E90 based on best fit in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and GOES CCOR-1.

cmes.note: CME first seen to the Southwest by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2026-02-04T20:24Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 and GOES CCOR-1 in later frames. This event is not visible in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap which began at 2026-02-04T15:53Z. The source of this CME is field line opening seen along the SW limb (approx. S21W85) in SDO AIA 171 beginning around 2026-02-04T19:00Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on source location and best fit in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and GOES CCOR-1.

cmes.note: Narrow, faint CME first seen to the East by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2026-02-04T20:48Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 and GOES CCOR-1 in later frames. This event is not visible in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap which began at 2026-02-04T15:53Z. The source of this is filament ejecta seen originating from beyond the Eastern limb in SDO AIA 304 beginning at approx. 2026-02-04T18:00Z, along with field line opening seen in SDO AIA 193.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky using a longitude of E90 due to source originating beyond the limb and lack of STEREO A COR2 to triangulate. Longitudes are fitting between E50 and E115.

cmes.note: This CME is visible to the east in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and GOES CCOR-1 imagery. This event is not seen in STEREO A COR2 imagery due to a data gap from 2026-02-04T15:53Z to 2026-02-05T03:38Z. The source is likely related to an eruption on the eastern limb (N05E90) starting around 2026-02-04T23:00Z as seen in SDO AIA 171/193/304 and GOES SUVI 171/195/304.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the source location. Due to a data gap in STEREO A COR2 imagery at the time of this event, the measured parameters may vary slightly.

cmes.note: Faint CME observed to the NW only in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, not observed in STEREO A COR2 and GOES CCOR-1 perhaps due to faintness of the front and/or a GOES CCOR-1 eclipse period. The source is a small filament located near AR 14359 (around N22W65), beginning to lift off around 2026-02-05T03:36Z observed as filament ejecta and brightening in SDO AIA 304 and field line movement in SDO AIA 171. The concurrent M2.5 and M2.7 flares from AR 14366 at this time are unrelated, and there is no exceptional brightening observed in SDO AIA 131 coupled to this eruption.

cmeAnalyses.note: SOHO LASCO C2 only 3D measurement using the eruptive source at N22W65, finding a good fit with minimal deflection, although some variation in the latitude/longitude is possible without triangulation here. LASCO C3's pylon obscures the faint front in running difference imagery.

cmes.note: Faint CME observed to the W in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and GOES CCOR-1, not observed in available STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source for this CME is observed as a helmet streamer breaking open over the west limb in GOES SUVI 171 starting around 2026-02-05T03:54Z, however it is difficult to trace down the latiude and longitude corresponding to the center of this feature.

cmeAnalyses.note: SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and GOES CCOR-1 plane-of-sky due to uncertain central coordinates of the observed streamer feature in GOES SUVI imagery. However, it is likely within W70-W110. Half width slightly less than 10 degrees.

cmes.note: This CME is visible to the southwest in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, GOES CCOR-1 and to the southeast in STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is likely related to a C6.0 flare and eruption from Active Region 14362 (S18W15) starting around 2026-02-05T12:50Z which exhibits southeast deflection as seen in SDO AIA 131/171/193/304 and GOES SUVI 131/171/195/284/304 imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

cmes.note: This CME is faint but visible to the south in SOHO LASCO C2 and to the southeast in STEREO A COR2 imagery for a few frames before becoming too diffuse to observe. The source may be related to a dimming region entered near S33E10 starting around 2026-02-05T13:00Z in SDO AIA 193 imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

cmes.note: CME observed to the S/SW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, greatly obscured by the pylon in GOES CCOR-1, and to the SE of STEREO A COR2 for 3 frames before a data gap begins at 2026-02-05T16:08Z. The source is likely associated with an M1.8 flare from AR 14362 (S18W17) which peaked at 2026-02-05T15:13Z, observed in SDO AIA 131. Following this flare, a large but faint southerly deflected EUV wave is observed causing a wide swath of dimming and field line wiggling to the south of this region observed in SDO AIA 171/193 and GOES SUVI 284, centered around S45W10 and spanning approximately E25-W30 and S30-S65. Multiple concentric fronts emerge in LASCO C2 following the intial 2026-02-05T15:48Z front, but these are considered part of the same complex bulk.

cmeAnalyses.note: BULK triangulation between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and three available STEREO A COR2 frames before its data gap. Multiple concentric fronts are observed in LASCO C2, treated as one front measuring on the leading most edge and capturing the full width of the brighter material.

SHOCK front analysis, of the very faint shock feature observed in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and even more faintly in STEREO A COR2. This feature is trackable enough in running difference imagery to get a triangulation, but difficult to properly discern the width, so this analysis is presented with some speculation but a good 3D fit between coronagraphs.

cmes.note: CME first seen to the SW by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2026-02-05T20:00Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 and to the SE in STEREO A COR2 in later frames. This event is not visible in GOES CCOR-1 due to being blocked by the pylon. The source of this event is an M2.2 flare from Active Region 14362 (S18W19) which peaked at 2026-02-05T22:17Z. A faint EUV wave and field line movement can be seen in SDO AIA 171/193 following this flare propagating towards the Southwest, suggesting a possible SW deflection.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. This fit suggests a SW deflection. Feature appears wider in SOHO LASCO than it does in STEREO A COR2.

cmes.note: Halo CME first seen to the NE by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2026-02-05T23:24Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 and GOES CCOR-1 in later frames. This CME is not currently visible in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap which began at 2026-02-05T23:38Z. The source of this event is far sided, as wide opening field lines can be seen beyond the NE limb in SDO AIA 171 and GOES SUVI 284. A far sided active region can be seen in NSO GONG located at approx. E150 degrees longitude, that may be responsible for this event.

cmeAnalyses.note: Updated measurement using a few frames of STEREO Ahead.
Preliminary measurement using early frames based on best fit in SOHO C2/C3 and GOES CCOR-1.

cmes.note: Faint CME visible to the SW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. There is no clear source for this CME. The CME is not visible in GOES CCOR-1 due to the placement of the control arm.

cmeAnalyses.note: Parameters based on best fit using SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

cmes.note: Faint CME visible to the SE in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and GOES CCOR-1. It is not visible in STEREO A COR2 imagery due to a data gap starting at 2026-02-06T19:38Z. The source appears to be a filament eruption with associated moving/opening field lines visible beyond the SE limb in SDO/AIA 304, 171, and 193 starting around 2026-02-06T22:48Z. This eruption is also visible in GOES SUVI 284 and 304 imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Preliminary plane-of-sky measurement using first available frames in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and GOES CCOR-1 imagery in SWPC_CAT.

cmes.note: Very faint narrow CME with two or three consecutive fronts (maybe the earliest one is a narrow shock), which is seen directly to the W in SOHO LASCO C2, and very faintly seen in C3. It is not seen in GOES CCOR-1 and STEREO A COR2. No clear source for this event has been found in EUV imagery, so it is most likely far-sided.

cmeAnalyses.note: The CME is not seen in STEREO A imagery and its source has not been found in EUV imagery, so only a plane-of-sky analysis is possible.

cmes.note: CME/streamer blowout with a very faint, fuzzy front seen to the SW in STEREO A COR2 and in SOHO LASCO C3. Its start is likely earlier, as in early COR2 and C3 timestamps this faint front is very hard to trace and it is not clearly seen in C2. The CME is obscured by the pylon in GOES CCOR-1. No source has been found for this CME in EUV imagery, so it is likely far-sided.

cmeAnalyses.note: Very approximate, speculative analysis based on an approximate fit of the very faint, fuzzy, uncertain front in STEREO A COR2 and SOHO LASCO C3.

cmes.note: A relatively bright narrow CME seen to the NNW in all three coronagraphs (SOHO LASCO C2/C3, STEREO A COR2 and GOES CCOR-1), partially obscured by the pylon in SOHO LASCO C3. Its source may be a minor eruption right behind the NW limb as seen (rather unclearly) in SDO AIA/GOES SUVI 304. Minor opening of field lines are also seen behind the limb in GOES SUVI 284 starting around 2026-02-07T09:00Z. This eruption is most clearly seen in STEREO A EUV 195 as slowly developing dimming centered around (N35W90) starting after 2026-02-07T09:00ZZ.

cmeAnalyses.note: Approximate analysis based on the fit with three coronagraphs (SOHO LASCO C2/C3, STEREO A COR2 and GOES CCOR-1) and confirmed by the location of the minor source eruption seen mostly in STEREO A EUVI 195 as minor dimming. There seems to be a northern deflection from the source location.

cmes.note: Faint CME to the NNW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and GOES CCOR-1 (partially obscured by pylon in C3), directed to the N in STEREO A COR2A, following and overlapping with 2026-02-07T09:36Z CME. No clear source found in EUV imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Analysis based solely on the fit of the faint, fuzzy front in all three coronagraphs (SOHO LASCO C2/C3, STEREO A COR2 and GOES CCOR-1). No clear source has been found in EUV imagery.

cmes.note: CME visible to the NE in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and GOES CCOR-1 imagery. The CME is not seen in STEREO A COR2 in real-time due to a data gap starting at 2026-02-07T16:38Z. The potential source may be seen as moving field lines in SDO AIA 171 in ISWA starting around 2026-02-07T19:21Z. A possible far-sided source candidate may be a region of interest seen in NSO GONG data, which may be former Active Region 14341, located approximately around longitude -145.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the potential source location in NSO GONG data.
Measurement of the wider, fainter shock feature.

cmes.note: Faint CME visible to the NW in SOHO LASCO C2 and GOES CCOR-1, preceding CME: 2026-02-07T23:00Z. The CME is not seen in STEREO A COR2 due to a real-time data gap starting at 2026-02-07T16:38Z and is obscured by the pylon in SOHO LASCO C3. There is no clear source seen in EUV imagery, and the CME is likely farsided.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane of sky measurement using SOHO LASCO C2 imagery in SWPC_CAT.

cmes.note: CME visible to the NW in SOHO LASCO C2 and GOES CCOR-1. The CME is obscured by the pylon in SOHO LASCO C3 and not visible in STEREO A COR2 in real-time due to a data gap starting at 2026-02-07T16:38Z. The potential source is a filament eruption, with liftoff best seen starting around 2026-02-07T21:00Z in GOES SUVI 304. Dimming can also be seen centered around N25W60 in SDO AIA 193.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on source location using available SOHO LASCO C2 and GOES CCOR-1 imagery.

cmes.note: Narrow CME first seen to the NE by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2026-02-08T08:00Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3, GOES CCOR-1 and STEREO A COR2 in later frames. The source of this event is field line opening/movement seen originating from the vicinity of AR14373 (N09E52) beginning at approx. 2026-02-08T07:04Z as seen in SDO AIA 171/193.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2.

cmes.note: CME first seen to the East by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2026-02-08T15:00Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 and GOES CCOR-1 in later frames. This CME is not visible in STEREO A COR2 likely due to it being directly far sided with respect to STEREO A. The source of this event is field line opening seen along the SE limb beginning around 2026-02-08T14:12Z as seen in SDO AIA 193.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky measurement using a longitude of E90 due to source near the limb and lack of triangulation. Longitude fits are between E45 and E130.

cmes.note: Faint CME seen along a NNE streamer first seen in SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2026-02-08T16:12Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3, STEREO A COR2 and GOES CCOR-1 in later frames. The source of this event is a small filament eruption seen along the NNE limb in SDO AIA 304 beginning around 2026-02-08T15:44Z, along with field line opening and post eruptive dimming seen in SDO AIA 171/193.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit in SOHO LASCO C3, GOES CCOR-1 and STEREO A COR2.

cmes.note: Faint minor CME seen to the SW in SOHO LASCO C2 and a couple of early C3 images before it dissipates. The CME is possibly covered by the pylon in GOES CCOR-1 (or too faint to be seen in this coronagraph); it is covered by the daily data gap in STEREO A COR2. Its source could be a minor opening of field lines on/behind the SW limb at the time seen in SDO AIA 193/304/131, and movement of field line behind the SW limb seen in GOES SUVI 284, however this is not a definitive source.

cmeAnalyses.note: The CME is fully covered by the daily data gap in STEREO A COR2 and no clear source has been found for it in EUV imagery. Plane-of-sky analysis is the only possible analysis; it is based on SOHO LASCO imagery.

cmes.note: Faint narrow CME/jet seen to the E in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and GOES CCOR-1. It is fully covered by the night time data gap in STEREO A COR2. No clear source has been found in EUV imagery for this event.

cmeAnalyses.note: This CME is fully covered by the night time data gap in STEREO A COR2. No source for this CME has been found in EUV imagery. Therefore, only plane-of-sky analysis is possible, using SOHO LASCO imagery.

cmes.note: CME visible to the west in SOHO LASCO C2/C3. Not clearly visible in GOES CCOR-1. There is a data gap in STEREO A COR2 from 2026-02-08T18:23Z to 2026-02-09T03:38Z, and the CME is not visible in the available imagery. The potential source may be an eruption with dimming centered around N15W50 best seen in SDO AIA 193 starting at 2026-02-08T23:04Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on potential source location using SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery. Limited available imagery was used, as the CME's leading edge fades away quickly.

cmes.note: CME visible to the east in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and GOES CCOR-1. There is a data gap in STEREO A COR2 from 2026-02-08T18:23Z to 2026-02-09T03:38Z, and the CME is not visible in available imagery. The potential source is an eruption on the east limb seen around latitude N10. The eruption is best seen as opening field lines in SDO AIA 171 in ISWA and GOES SUVI 284 starting at 2026-02-09T00:09Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on potential source location on the east limb. Due to the uncertainty in the source eruption location, the longitude may vary by approximately +/- 10 degrees.

cmes.note: CME first seen to the East by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2026-02-09T23:24Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 and GOES CCOR-1 in later frames. This event is not visible in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap from 2026-02-09T18:53Z to 2026-02-10T03:38Z. The source of this CME is a C9.2 flare from Active Region 14374 (N10E75) which peaked at 2026-02-09T23:02Z, along with a small amount of associated filament ejecta exhibiting a heavy Southern deflection. This flare is visible in SDO AIA 131, along with field line movement seen in SDO AIA 171/193 and ejecta visible in SDO AIA 304.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and GOES CCOR-1.

cmes.note: CME first seen to the NE by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2026-02-10T09:48Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 and GOES CCOR-1 in later frames. This event is not visible in STEREO A COR2 due to being directly far sided with respect to the STEREO A spacecraft. The source of this event is a small eruption from Active Region 14374 (N11E67) which began around 2026-02-10T09:14Z as seen in SDO AIA 131/171/193.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit on SOHO LASCO C2 and GOE CCOR-1. This feature appears to exhibit a strong Northern deflection.
